children: A 33-year-old man is evaluated for severe retrosternal chest pain following an episode of protracted forceful vomiting.
Chest
radiographs
are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely cause of the chest radiograph findings?
The chest radiographs show a pneumomediastinum, which may be seen with spontaneous esophageal perforation (Boerhaave syndrome). Pneumomediastinum (air within the mediastinal space) is
shown
in the image below by the presence of hyperlucent areas (
white arrows

) surrounding and making more prominent the contours of mediastinal structures, such as the border of the heart and aorta. The air has laterally displaced the mediastinal pleura, which can be seen on the frontal radiograph (left panel) as a long linear opacity (
white arrowheads
); subcutaneous emphysema (air within the soft tissues) is also seen (
yellow arrow

objective.__html: Diagnose effort-related esophageal rupture and associated pneumomediastinum.

children: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for abdominal fullness, nausea, and early satiety. She had an episode of gallstone pancreatitis 5 weeks ago.
Abdominal CT
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

text.__html: Pancreatic pseudocyst and gastric outlet obstruction

children: The most likely diagnosis is a pancreatic pseudocyst and gastric outlet obstruction. This CT scan shows a large fluid collection at the head of the pancreas with well-defined margins, features that are characteristic of a pancreatic pseudocyst. In this case, the pancreatic pseudocyst is also causing gastric outlet obstruction. Pseudocysts of the pancreas are caused by pancreatic inflammation and necrosis. They may be single or multiple, small or large, and within or outside the pancreas. Most pseudocysts communicate with the pancreatic ductal system and contain high concentrations of digestive enzymes. The walls of pseudocysts are formed by adjacent structures, such as the stomach, transverse mesocolon, gastrocolic omentum, and pancreas.

objective.__html: Diagnose a pancreatic pseudocyst on the basis of CT findings.

title: Question 3

children: A 26-year-old woman has a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome and a recent pruritic eruption on her buttocks, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is celiac disease manifested by gastrointestinal symptoms and dermatitis herpetiformis. Dermatitis herpetiformis is characterized by grouped, pruritic, erythematous papulovesicles and erosions that typically occur over the extensor surfaces of the arms, legs, central back, buttocks, and scalp. Because of intense pruritus, erosions and excoriations are the most common clinical finding, as
shown
in the image below of a different patient.

A genetic predisposition is linked to the same genes associated with celiac disease. Almost all patients with dermatitis herpetiformis have histologic evidence of celiac disease, but gastrointestinal symptoms occur in only about 25% of patients.

figureCredits: Image in the stem reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 60-year-old man is evaluated for iron deficiency anemia. Colonoscopy is normal. Upper endoscopy identifies a gastric lesion, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is gastric angiodysplasia. Angiodysplasias are composed of ectatic, dilated, thin-walled vessels and may occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract, but they are most commonly reported in the colon. Other synonymous terms include arteriovenous malformation, angiectasia, and vascular ectasia. Telangiectasia may be used in the context of a hereditary disease, such as hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. Although the prevalence of angiodysplasia increases with age, and most cases are without a clear cause, associations of gastrointestinal angiodysplasia with advanced chronic kidney disease, von Willebrand disease, and aortic stenosis have been reported.
A 50-year-old woman is evaluated for dysphagia.
Images
from left to right show the appearance of the esophagus 1 minute, 3 minutes, and 5 minutes after ingestion of barium.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is achalasia, a hypertonic motility condition defined by inadequate relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter and aperistalsis. Barium esophagography shows dilation of the esophagus with narrowing at the gastroesophageal junction, known as a “bird's beak,” and absence of peristalsis. Achalasia can be idiopathic or associated with autoimmune conditions, neurodegenerative disorders, and infection (Chagas disease).
A 23-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with fulminant liver failure and hemolytic anemia. She has a history of behavioral problems.
Ocular findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is hepatolenticular degeneration (Wilson disease). The patient's ocular findings show Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are circumferential discolorations that occur in the cornea due to copper deposition in the Descemet membrane. The finding is most easily visible at the inferior and superior poles and usually is seen only on slit-lamp examination. Kayser-Fleischer rings are associated with Wilson disease but are not pathognomonic for it.

A 58-year-old woman undergoes colonoscopy for evaluation of chronic, watery diarrhea. Testing for celiac disease and stool examination for pathogens are negative. She is otherwise well and maintains a normal weight.
Representative histology findings are
shown
Which of the following diagnoses is most compatible with this colonoscopy finding?

This patient's colonoscopy findings show normal colonic mucosa without evidence of inflammation or ulceration, which is characteristic of microscopic colitis. Microscopic colitis has two subtypes: lymphocytic colitis and collagenous colitis. The diagnosis must be established by mucosal biopsy. Both subtypes of microscopic colitis
demonstrate
lamina propria inflammation (
arrow
); a predominance of intraepithelial lymphocytes is seen in lymphocytic colitis; a thickened subepithelial collagen band is seen in collagenous colitis (
arrowhead

). This patient's biopsy results are consistent with collagenous colitis. Microscopic colitis usually presents with chronic, watery diarrhea, typically in middle-aged patients; women are more likely to be affected than men. Certain medications (NSAIDS, proton pump inhibitors) and smoking may be possible risk factors for the development of microscopic colitis.

objective.__html: Identify characteristic colonoscopy findings in microscopic colitis.

children: A 33-year-old man is evaluated after several episodes of esophageal meat impaction. An
upper endoscopy
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE), a condition commonly associated with dysphagia and food bolus obstruction. The macroscopic findings of EoE at endoscopy are nonspecific, but mucosal furrowing, appearing as stacked esophageal rings, white specks, and mucosal friability, has been consistently described. Most patients are diagnosed between the second and fifth decades of life; EoE is more commonly seen in men. Patients often have other atopic conditions, such as asthma, rhinitis, dermatitis, and seasonal or food allergies.
A 29-year-old woman is evaluated for acute epigastric pain associated with nausea and vomiting.
A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient most likely has interstitial pancreatitis, which is an acute pancreatitis without necrosis. The CT scan shows enlargement of the gland, with contour irregularities and edema. Patients with interstitial pancreatitis have an intact capillary network with vasodilation and therefore should exhibit uniform enhancement of the pancreatic gland. Conversely, areas of necrotizing pancreatitis are associated with a lack of contrast enhancement. Typical imaging findings of acute pancreatitis include pancreatic edema and peripancreatic stranding.

objective.__html: Diagnose interstitial pancreatitis on the basis of CT findings.

children: A 32-year-old woman undergoes
colonoscopy
for evaluation of chronic bloody diarrhea associated with occasional tenesmus.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is ulcerative colitis. The findings on colonoscopy show a continuous pattern of inflammation of varying severity with mucosal granularity, edema, loss of the normal vascular pattern, friability, and ulceration, which are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. A diffuse pattern of microulcerations is commonly seen, and frank ulcers are atypical. This pattern of inflammation usually involves the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous and circumferential pattern. The transition from abnormal to normal tissue is usually abrupt, with a very clear line of demarcation. This pattern differs from Crohn disease, in which areas of discrete inflammation and ulceration are separated by normal mucosa (“skip lesions”).
A 55-year-old woman undergoes routine colorectal cancer screening.
Colonoscopy findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is colon cancer. On colonoscopy, most colorectal cancers appear as masses arising from the mucosa and protruding into the bowel lumen. Some colon cancers may show evidence of bleeding or friability on colonoscopy, as seen in this patient. Most colon cancers are adenocarcinomas that begin in the inner lining and progress to involve or spread beyond the full thickness of the bowel wall, then to regional lymph nodes, and subsequently to distant organ metastases.
A 30-year-old man is evaluated for ongoing symptoms of odynophagia. He is a recent hematopoietic cell transplant recipient.
Upper endoscopy
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The small, raised, white mucosal plaque-like lesions pictured are consistent with a diagnosis of candidal esophagitis. This invasive mucosal infection caused by
Candida

species occurs most frequently in patients with deficiencies in cell-mediated immunity associated with conditions such as AIDS and lymphoid malignancies. Candidal esophagitis can also be seen in patients with hematologic malignancies, following hematopoietic stem cell transplantation; while receiving cytotoxic chemotherapy for solid organ cancers; and occasionally in patients using inhaled glucocorticoids for pulmonary disease. The most common symptom is odynophagia rather than dysphagia. Diagnosis is confirmed by brushings that show pseudohyphae invading mucosal cells and a culture that grows
Candida
. Although esophagitis and thrush (oral candidiasis) often occur together in patients who are immunosuppressed, the absence of thrush does not exclude the diagnosis of esophagitis.

objective.__html: Diagnose candidal esophagitis on upper endoscopy.

children: A 36-year-old man with ulcerative colitis is evaluated for a 5-day history of abdominal pain, diarrhea, fever, and leukocytosis.
A plain radiograph of the abdomen is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is toxic megacolon. The abdominal radiograph shows extensive colonic distension consistent with toxic megacolon. The presence of systemic findings (such as fever, tachycardia, and leukocytosis) distinguishes toxic megacolon from isolated colonic distension. Multiple air-fluid levels are usually seen, and the normal haustral markings may be distorted. Toxic megacolon is associated with inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease) but may also occur with infectious colitis (particularly
Clostridioides difficile

infection), diverticulitis, volvulus, and obstructing colon cancer. The right and transverse segments of the colon are the most commonly dilated, often exceeding 6 cm in diameter on plain radiograph; the descending segment and sigmoid colon are often much less affected.

objective.__html: Diagnose toxic megacolon associated with inflammatory bowel disease on plain abdominal radiograph.

children: A 58-year-old man is evaluated for lower abdominal and pelvic discomfort, guarding, and fever.
A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
This patient's CT findings
show
numerous diverticula (
white arrows

indicating the largest of these). These sac-like protrusions, usually measuring 5 to 10 mm in diameter, may result from anatomic weakness where the vasa recta penetrate the colon wall, motility factors (simultaneous or excessive haustral contractions), and dietary causes (decreased fiber intake). Diverticula are most commonly seen in the sigmoid and descending colon and increase in prevalence with age. Diverticula may be clinically symptomatic, particularly if extensive; may be associated with inflammation (diverticulitis) resulting from micro- or macroscopic perforation; or may cause bleeding because of abnormal mechanical exposure of the mucosal vasculature. CT findings of acute diverticulitis include bowel wall thickening and an increase in soft tissue density within the pericolonic fat secondary to inflammation (
red arrows

objective.__html: Identify characteristic CT findings of sigmoid diverticulosis and diverticulitis.

children: A 20-year-old man is evaluated for lower gastrointestinal bleeding. A
colonoscopy
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome (FAP), an inherited disorder characterized by multiple (usually >100) adenomatous colon polyps. FAP is caused by germline mutations in the adenomatous polyposis coli gene that are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, although de novo mutations occur in about 25% of cases. Adenomas in classic FAP are more numerous in the distal colon than in the proximal colon. Adenoma and cancer develop in 100% of classic FAP cases if surgery is not performed. The average age of colorectal cancer onset in patients with FAP is 39 years, with a risk of 93% by age 50 years.
A 45-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-month history of a burning sensation in the anterior chest, usually after meals, that has been unresponsive to twice-daily proton pump inhibitor therapy.
Upper endoscopy results are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Erosive esophagitis is characterized by the presence of superficial esophageal erosions, which may be associated with minor bleeding. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is caused by reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus and can be divided into two groups, erosive esophagitis and nonerosive reflux disease. Obesity is a risk factor for GERD and erosive esophagitis.
A 56-year-old man with portal hypertension due to alcoholic cirrhosis undergoes screening upper
endoscopy
Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?

The upper endoscopy image shows changes consistent with portal hypertensive gastropathy, which most commonly occurs with portal hypertension. The classic endoscopic finding is a white reticular pattern separated by areas of pink mucosa, causing a "snakeskin" appearance of the stomach, primarily in the fundus and body. Blood flow to the gastric mucosa is increased in patients with portal hypertension, and gastropathy may relate to hyperemia and congestion. Portal hypertensive gastropathy is rarely a cause of significant bleeding and is most commonly associated with diffuse mucosal oozing and chronic blood loss.

objective.__html: Diagnose portal hypertensive gastropathy associated with portal hypertension.

children: A 36-year-old woman is evaluated for abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant and fever of 1 month's duration. She emigrated from Guatemala 5 months ago. A contrast-enhanced
CT
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is hepatic abscess, most likely an amebic abscess. CT scan of an amebic liver abscess will show a heterogeneous lesion that is round to oval with irregular margins and possible peripheral contrast enhancement, as seen in this image. Internal septations are also common (but not well visualized in this image). Amebic abscesses of the liver are found in developing areas of the world or in migrants from countries in which amebiasis is endemic. Intestinal infection with amoebae can result in invasion of the portal vein and migration to the liver. Typical symptoms of amebic liver abscesses include right-upper-quadrant abdominal pain and fever. Hepatic imaging and serologic testing establish the diagnosis of amebic liver abscess.

objective.__html: Diagnose a hepatic abscess on the basis of CT findings.

children: A 47-year-old man is evaluated for chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea. An IgG4 level is normal.
A frontal plane CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is chronic pancreatitis, as evidenced by chronic coarse calcifications distributed in the body and tail of the pancreas on the frontal plane CT scan. Diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis remains challenging because hallmark anatomic features, such as pancreatic calcifications, occur in only 25% of patients, and other features of atrophy or duct dilation can occur normally with aging or other disease processes. Imaging with CT or MRI is the initial test of choice.

objective.__html: Diagnose chronic pancreatitis on the basis of CT findings.

children: A 78-year-old man develops crampy lower abdominal pain followed 24 hours later with bloody diarrhea.
Colonoscopy findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient's symptoms and colonoscopy findings are most consistent with colonic ischemia. In the acute stage, the mucosa is frequently pale with areas of petechial bleeding. More severe disease may show hemorrhagic ulcerations and bluish nodules resulting from submucosal bleeding
shown
; these are the equivalent to "thumbprints" (which represent edema and bowel wall thickening) detected on other imaging studies such as CT.

Colonic ischemia is usually the result of reduced blood flow, most commonly in the watershed regions of the colon between perfusing vessels, where there is less blood flow in the microvasculature compared with other areas. Acute colonic ischemia usually presents with rapid onset of mild cramping, abdominal pain, and tenderness over the affected bowel, with variable amounts of bleeding within 24 hours of pain onset.

title: Question 21

children: A 49-year-old man has severe rectal pain with passage of stool. The pain began abruptly after passage of a large, hard stool.
Perianal findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
This patient has an acute anal fissure. Anal
fissures

are longitudinal mucosal tears in the anal canal characterized by anorectal pain worsened by bowel movements and sitting. Rectal bleeding with bowel movements or wiping is also frequently reported. Anal fissures are most commonly idiopathic or traumatic, resulting from the passage of hard stool. Additional causes include receptive anal intercourse, enemas, or endoscopy.

figureCredits: Image courtesy of Richard E. Burney, MD, Professor of Surgery, Michigan Medicine at the University of Michigan.

children: A 56-year-old woman with alcohol use disorder is evaluated for an episode of large volume hematemesis.
Upper endoscopy
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely source of this patient's bleeding?

The most likely diagnosis is a bleeding esophageal varix. Esophageal varices are enlarged vessels within the lumen of the lower esophagus that provide extrahepatic pathways of blood flow from the portal circulation to the systemic circulation. Over time, esophageal varices enlarge and may spontaneously rupture, leading to bleeding and possible death.
A 47-year-old man is evaluated for abdominal pain. He has a history of sclerosing sialadenitis.
A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP). Diagnostic criteria for AIP require imaging findings of a narrowed main pancreatic duct and parenchymal swelling (“sausage-shaped” pancreas) as
shown
arrows

) and response to glucocorticoids. A significant elevation of serum IgG4 level is helpful in diagnosing type 1 AIP. Patients with type 1 AIP also have elevated levels of IgG4-positive cells in pancreatic tissue (>10 IgG4-positive cells/hpf), and 60% to 80% of patients have associated sclerosing cholangitis, sclerosing sialadenitis, or retroperitoneal fibrosis.
A 65-year-old woman with osteoarthritis is evaluated for epigastric pain and iron deficiency anemia.
Upper endoscopy
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The endoscopic image of this patient shows inflammation in the prepyloric area of the stomach with a shallow ulcer in the upper left (10 o’clock) portion of the image, consistent with peptic ulcer disease. On endoscopy, gastritis is seen as areas of mucosal erythema and edema, possibly with erosions associated with disruption of the normal mucosal barrier. Benign gastrointestinal ulcers have smooth, regular, rounded edges and a flat, smooth ulcer base that is often filled with exudate.

objective.__html: Identify peptic ulcer disease on upper endoscopy.

children: A 59-year-old man with chronic hepatitis B virus infection is evaluated for a recently discovered hepatic mass. The CT scan
shown
represents the arterial phase of contrast administration.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Four-phase CT (unenhanced, arterial, portal venous, and delayed) is highly effective and is recommended for the detection and staging of hepatocellular carcinoma. The early arterial phase is best for imaging hypervascular lesions, which appear as areas of increased enhancement relative to the unenhanced liver parenchyma, as in this image.
A 32-year-old man is evaluated for upper gastrointestinal bleeding following repeated bouts of vomiting.
Upper endoscopy
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is a Mallory-Weiss tear, a longitudinal mucosal laceration typically occurring in the distal esophagus and proximal stomach that frequently results in bleeding from injured submucosal arteries. Mallory-Weiss tears are usually associated with forceful retching that may result from vomiting, straining, or coughing. Patients may have pain in the epigastric region, although pain may also radiate to the back. Upper endoscopy is the diagnostic method of choice, because it may also allow therapeutic intervention for actively bleeding lesions.

objective.__html: Diagnose a Mallory-Weiss tear on upper endoscopy.

children: A 50-year-old woman is evaluated for slowly progressive esophageal dysphagia over several years. A
barium swallow
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is a Schatzki ring, which is characterized by an isolated ring occurring in the distal esophagus that causes intermittent dysphagia. Esophageal dysphagia is the result of one of two underlying causes: a mechanical obstruction or a motility disorder. Dysphagia occurring with solid food alone suggests a mechanical obstruction, whereas dysphagia with either liquids alone or the combination of liquids and solids favors a motility disorder. Mechanical esophageal obstruction may be benign or malignant and may be caused by an esophageal ring (e.g., Schatzki ring), webs, strictures, or masses. Upper endoscopy allows for diagnosis (biopsy and inspection) and therapeutic intervention (dilation).
A 68-year-old man is evaluated for intermittent left-lower-quadrant discomfort and fever associated with recent-onset constipation. A
colonoscopy
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Diverticulitis is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms. This patient's colonoscopy depicts multiple diverticula in the sigmoid colon, with the central diverticulum showing evidence of inflammation with surrounding erythema and purulent drainage (along with some blood), consistent with diverticulitis. Diverticula are sac-like protrusions that typically occur where the vasa recta penetrate the colon wall, most commonly in the sigmoid and descending colon, as
shown
on this contrast-enhanced CT scan.

Diverticula are generally asymptomatic but may become inflamed because of micro- or macroscopic perforation. Symptoms include abdominal pain, fever, and altered bowel habits. If clinical features are highly suggestive of diverticulitis, imaging is unnecessary. If the diagnosis is unclear or if an abscess is suspected (severe pain, high fever, palpable mass), CT is indicated. Endoscopy is generally avoided in patients with acute diverticulitis because of the potential for perforation.
A 61-year-old man with obesity has a 5-year history of nearly daily gastroesophageal reflux disease. An
upper endoscopy
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Barrett esophagus, which is defined as the extension of the metaplastic columnar epithelium above the gastroesophageal junction into the esophagus. Endoscopically, Barrett esophagus is recognized as salmon-colored mucosa compared with the normal pearl-colored squamous mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Barrett esophagus is a consequence of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), even in patients who experience no clinical symptoms, and is classified as a premalignant condition because it has the potential to progress to esophageal cancer. Risk factors associated with Barrett esophagus include chronic GERD (>5 years), older than age 50 years, male sex, tobacco use, and obesity.
A 39-year-old woman is evaluated for acute-onset, right-upper-quadrant spasmodic pain. Focused ultrasonography of the gallbladder is performed.
(Note that there is no sound for this
video
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is gallstones. The focused ultrasonography shows the liver (on the left) and the gallbladder in long axis with multiple stones present. The stones appear hyperechoic (white) with shadowing artifact posteriorly, consistent with cholelithiasis. The lumen of a normal gallbladder should appear anechoic (black). It is important to scan through the gallbladder to ensure the entire lumen is visualized before determining whether stones are absent. An indeterminate study would occur if the gallbladder cannot be completely visualized, usually because of underdistention secondary to lack of fasting.
A 33-year-old man is evaluated for a 3-month history of fever, rectal pain during defecation, and intermittent and malodorous perianal drainage and pruritus.
The perianal skin is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Crohn disease. This patient most likely has a bleeding anal fistula due to Crohn disease. Numerous skin tags, which are commonly associated with the disease, are present. Patients with Crohn disease may present with fistulizing disease and have pneumaturia, fecaluria, and recurrent or polymicrobial urinary tract infections (caused by enterovesical fistulas); dyspareunia and vaginal drainage of feces (caused by enterovaginal fistulas); or seepage of bowel contents through the skin (caused by enterocutaneous fistulas). Crohn disease may affect any segment of the gastrointestinal tract, is often discontinuous, and may cause transmural inflammation.

objective.__html: Diagnose an anal fistula associated with Crohn disease.

children: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated for a 5-year history of lower abdominal pain and weight loss. A
colonoscopy
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Crohn colitis. A characteristic mucosal feature of Crohn disease seen on colonoscopy is the so-called “skip lesion,” consisting of affected areas separated by normal mucosa. The earliest endoscopic findings of Crohn disease include aphthous ulcers, which can coalesce to form stellate ulcers, and a “cobblestone” mucosal appearance.
A 39-year old pregnant woman is evaluated during a routine visit. Incidentally found skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is spider angioma. Spider angiomas are vascular lesions characterized by a prominent central papular punctum, which is the site of dilated capillaries radiating from a central arteriole. They are typically found on the chest, face, and upper limbs. Spider angiomas are often seen in patients with cirrhosis and during normal pregnancy. Cherry angioma are small, circular dome-shaped collections of capillaries that, unlike spider angioma, do not blanch with pressure. Bed bug bites are pruritic erythematous papules that often occur in groups of two to four, most commonly on the trunk.
A 29-year-old woman with Crohn disease has a painful chronic ulcer near her ostomy site, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is pyoderma gangrenosum. Lesions can be single or multiple and usually appear on the lower extremities and near ostomy sites. Diseases most commonly associated with pyoderma gangrenosum are inflammatory bowel diseases, rheumatoid arthritis, seronegative spondyloarthritis, and hematologic disease or malignancy, most commonly acute myeloid leukemia.
A 33-year-old man with ulcerative colitis is evaluated for the recent onset of cholestatic liver disease.
Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography results are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), an autoimmune fibroinflammatory disease of the bile ducts. PSC is associated with inflammatory bowel disease in about 85% of cases; up to 7.5% of patients with ulcerative colitis have PSC. The diagnosis of PSC can be made noninvasively through magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP). This patient's MRCP
shows
multifocal intra- and extrahepatic bile-duct stricturing with a dominant left-lobe stricture (
arrow
) and upstream bile-duct dilation, consistent with the diagnosis of PSC.
A 33-year-old man is hospitalized for acute abdominal pain that radiates to his back associated with nausea and vomiting. He appears severely ill. A contrast-enhanced
CT
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is necrotizing pancreatitis. On contrast-enhanced abdominal CT, pancreatic necrosis is recognized as areas without contrast enhancement, reflecting lack of blood flow to devitalized tissue. Thickening of fascial planes can also be seen, as can hyperdense areas secondary to hemorrhage in patients with hemorrhagic pancreatitis. This severe form of acute pancreatitis is associated with proteolytic destruction of the pancreatic parenchyma.
